document.p: If you connect a USB storage device to the 's USB port, you can share the content on your USB storage device(s) with other devices that are connected to your local network (mostly computers).
These devices have read and write access to this USB device(s).
The uses the following servers to share your content:
document.li1: The file server allows you to share all types of files with devices on your local network (mostly computers).
The DLNA server allows you to share media files with DLNA-certified devices (e.g. media players, set-top boxes, smart TVs) on your local network.

document.li1: The status of the file server
The status of the DLNA server
document.p: To open the Content Sharing page, click the Content Sharing card in the Advanced View .
The content sharing settings are grouped into the following sections:
document.li2:
File Server Enabled
Allows you to enable or disable the file server.

File Server name
Determines under which name the media files will be shared with other DLNA-enabled devices.

File Server workgroup
Enter the same workgroup as used by your computer(s).

File Server description
Add a short description for the shared content.

DLNA Enabled
Allows you to enable or disable the DLNA server.

DLNA name
Determines under which name the media files will be shared with other DLNA-enabled devices.

document.li1: A device that’s contains proper media files that can be recognized by Supported files types (see below); for example, a USB Hard disk.
A device that’s compatible with Digital Living Network Alliance (DLNA); for example, a PC running Windows with the DLNA client software installed , like XBMC http://kodi.tv/download/ .
